title: Rolling - block and hoop on ramp

content.question: A block and a hoop, both having the same mass, are released from rest at equal heights <math alttext="H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>H</mi></math> above the floor on identical rough tracks, as shown. Both objects move down the track, with the block sliding and the hoop rolling without slipping. Each object then moves up a short, curved ramp and is launched vertically upward. Each object’s center of mass comes to rest momentarily at a height <math alttext="The fraction H over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>H</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math> above the floor. A student claims that the total mechanical energies of the block-Earth system and the hoop-Earth system are equal when the centers of mass of the objects are momentarily at rest at height <math alttext="The fraction H over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>H</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>. Is the student’s claim correct? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because both systems start with the same gravitational potential energy.
Yes, because both objects have zero kinetic energy when their centers of mass are momentarily at rest.
No, because the work done by gravity is not the same for both objects.
No, because when the center of mass of the hoop is momentarily at rest it has nonzero rotational kinetic energy.

content.answer: No, because when the center of mass of the hoop is momentarily at rest it has nonzero rotational kinetic energy.

unit.text: 6: Energy and Momentum of Rotating Systems

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
